name: Kepler-431
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-431 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-431 is a star with 1.07 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.09 times its radius. It is located 1609.38 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-431 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-431 b

Kepler-431 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2015-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.80 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-431.

The mass of Kepler-431 b is 0.50 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-431 b is 0.764 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-431 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-431 c

Kepler-431 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2015-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.70 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-431.

The mass of Kepler-431 c is 0.37 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-431 c is 0.668 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-431 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-431 d

Kepler-431 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2015-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.92 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-431.

The mass of Kepler-431 d is 1.27 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-431 d is 1.11 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-431 d is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-431, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
